page 10] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019223055/http://legal.un.org/repertory/art102/english/rep_supp8_vol6-art102_e_advance.pdf |date=19 October 2013 }} | area_km2 = 236.7 | area_rank = {{small|unranked}} | area_sq_mi = 91 | percent_water = | population_estimate = {{UN_Population|Cook Islands}}{{UN_Population|ref}} | population_census = 17,459{{Cite web|url=http://www.mfem.gov.ck/census|title=Census 2016 - Cook Islands - Ministry of Finance and Economic Management|website=www.mfem.gov.ck|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-11-11}} | population_estimate_year = {{UN_Population|Year}} | population_census_year = 2016 | population_density_km2 = 42 | population_density_sq_mi = 111 | population_density_rank = 124th | GDP_PPP = $311 million{{cite web|url=http://data.un.org/CountryProfile.aspx?crName=Cook%20Islands|title=UN Data|accessdate=7 January 2017}} | GDP_PPP_year = 2014 | GDP_PPP_rank = {{nowrap|{{small|not ranked}}}} | GDP_PPP_per_capita = $15,002.5 | GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = {{nowrap|{{small|not ranked}}}} | HDI = | HDI_year = | HDI_rank = | currency = {{nowrap|[[New Zealand dollar]] ([[ISO 4217|NZD]])
[[Cook Islands dollar]]}} | currency_code = | time_zone = CKT | utc_offset = -10 | utc_offset_DST = | time_zone_DST = | drives_on = [[Right- and left-hand traffic|left]] | calling_code = +682 | iso3166code = CK | cctld = [[.ck]] | footnote_a = {{Note|a}} As per the [http://www.paclii.org/ck/legis/num_act/trma2003130/ Te Reo Maori Act]. | area_magnitude = | HDI_category = }} The '''Cook Islands''' ([[Cook Islands Māori]]: ''Kūki 'Āirani'')[https://books.google.com/books?id=AT2ENAHoS28C ''Cook Islands Maori dictionary''] by Jasper Buse & Raututi Taringa, Cook Islands Ministry of Education (1995) page 200 is a self-governing [[island country]] in the [[Pacific Ocean|South Pacific Ocean]] in [[Associated state|free association]] with [[New Zealand]]. It comprises 15 islands whose total land area is {{convert|240|km2|sqmi|1}}. The Cook Islands' [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] (EEZ) covers {{convert|1800000|km2|sqmi}} of ocean.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070214035426/http://www.sopac.org/tiki/tiki-index.php?page=Cook+Islands A View from the Cook Islands]. SOPAC New Zealand is responsible for the Cook Islands' defence and foreign affairs, but they are exercised in consultation with the Cook Islands. In recent times, the Cook Islands have adopted an increasingly independent foreign policy. Although [[Cook Islanders]] are [[New Zealand nationality law|citizens of New Zealand]], they have the status of Cook Islands nationals, which is not given to other New Zealand citizens. The Cook Islands' main population centres are on the island of [[Rarotonga]] (10,572 in 2011),{{cite web|url=http://www.cookislands.org.uk/2011census|title=Cook Islands 2011 census|website=Cookislands.org|accessdate=22 March 2015}} where there is an international airport. There is a larger population of Cook Islanders in New Zealand itself; in the 2013 census, 61,839 people said they were Cook Islanders, or of Cook Islands descent.{{Cite web|url=http://www.stats.govt.nz/Census/2013-census/profile-and-summary-reports/ethnic-profiles.aspx?request_value=24709&parent_id=24706&tabname=#24709|title=2013 Census ethnic group profiles|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Statistics NZ|access-date=2017-11-11}} With about 100,000 visitors travelling to the islands in the 2010–11 financial year,{{cite web|url=http://www.mfem.gov.ck/docs/Treasury/Budget/2010-11/BPS%20n%20HYEFU/Combined%20HYEFU%202010-11.pdf|title=The Cook Islands Half Year Economic and Fiscal Update For the Financial Year 2010/2011|publisher=Cook Islands Ministry of Finance & Economic Management|page=7|date=December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720202328/http://www.mfem.gov.ck/docs/Treasury/Budget/2010-11/BPS%20n%20HYEFU/Combined%20HYEFU%202010-11.pdf|archivedate=20 July 2012|df=dmy-all}} tourism is the country's main industry, and the leading element of the economy, ahead of [[offshore banking]], pearls, and marine and fruit exports. ==Geography== {{Main|Geography of the Cook Islands}}The Cook Islands are in the South Pacific Ocean, northeast of New Zealand, between [[French Polynesia]] and [[American Samoa]]. There are 15 major islands spread over {{convert|2200000|km²|0|abbr=on}} of ocean, divided into two distinct groups: the Southern Cook Islands and the Northern Cook Islands of [[Atoll|coral atolls]]."Cook Islands Travel Guide" (with description), ''World Travel Guide'', Nexus Media Communications, 2006. Webpage: [http://www.worldtravelguide.net/country/65/country_guide/Australia-and-South-Pacific/Cook-Islands.html WTGuide-Cook-Islands] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061026060558/http://www.worldtravelguide.net/country/65/country_guide/Australia-and-South-Pacific/Cook-Islands.html |date=26 October 2006 }}. The islands were formed by [[volcanic]] activity; the northern group is older and consists of six atolls, which are sunken volcanoes topped by coral growth. The climate is [[Oceanic climate|moderate]] to [[Tropical climate|tropical]]. [[File:Aitutaki-Motu Tapuaetai.jpg|thumb|[[Tapuaetai]] (One Foot Island) in the southern part of [[Aitutaki Atoll]]]] The Cook Islands consist of 15 islands and two reefs. {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Group ! Island ! Area km² ! Population 2016 |- | Northern | [[Penrhyn (atoll)|Penrhyn]] | style='text-align:right;' | 10 | style='text-align:right;' | 226 |- | Northern | [[Rakahanga]] | style='text-align:right;' | 4 | style='text-align:right;' | 80 |- | Northern | [[Manihiki]] | style='text-align:right;' | 5 | style='text-align:right;' | 213 |- | Northern | [[Pukapuka]] | style='text-align:right;' | 1 | style='text-align:right;' | 444 |- | Northern | [[Tema Reef]] (submerged) | style='text-align:right;' | 0 | style='text-align:right;' | 0 |- | Northern | [[Nassau (Cook Islands)|Nassau]] | style='text-align:right;' | 1 | style='text-align:right;' | 78 |- | Northern | [[Suwarrow]] | style='text-align:right;' | 0 | style='text-align:right;' | 0 |- | Southern | [[Palmerston Island|Palmerston]] | style='text-align:right;' | 2 | style='text-align:right;' | 58 |- | Southern | [[Aitutaki]] | style='text-align:right;' | 18 | style='text-align:right;' | 1,928 |- | Southern | [[Manuae (Cook Islands)|Manuae]] | style='text-align:right;' | 6 | style='text-align:right;' | 0 |- | Southern | [[Takutea]] | style='text-align:right;' | 1 | style='text-align:right;' | 0 |- | Southern | [[Mitiaro]] | style='text-align:right;' | 22 | style='text-align:right;' | 155 |- | Southern | [[Atiu]] | style='text-align:right;' | 27 | style='text-align:right;' | 437 |- | Southern | [[Mauke]] | style='text-align:right;' | 18 | style='text-align:right;' | 297 |- | Southern | [[Winslow Reef, Cook Islands|Winslow Reef]] (submerged) | style='text-align:right;' | 0 | style='text-align:right;' | 0 |- | Southern | [[Rarotonga]] | style='text-align:right;' | 67 | style='text-align:right;' | 13,044 |- | Southern | [[Mangaia]] | style='text-align:right;' | 52 | style='text-align:right;' | 499 |- ! Total ! Total ! style='text-align:right;' | 237 ! style='text-align:right;' | 17,459 |} The table is ordered from north to south. Population figures from the 2016 census.[http://www.mfem.gov.ck/census Cook Islands Ministry of Finance and Economic Management, 2016 Census] [[File:Wyspy Cooka.png|left|thumb|Map of the Cook Islands.]] ==History== {{Main|History of the Cook Islands}} [[File:rarotonga beach.jpg|thumb|left|Beach on [[Rarotonga]]]] The Cook Islands were first settled in the 6th century by [[Polynesian people]] who migrated from [[Tahiti]],[https://web.archive.org/web/20120319005759/http://www.samoa2007.ws/index.php?id=224 Cook Islands] (archived from [http://www.samoa2007.ws/index.php?id=224 the original] on 19 March 2012). an island {{convert|1154|km}} to the northeast. Spanish ships visited the islands in the 16th century; the first written record of contact with the islands came in 1595 with the sighting of [[Pukapuka]] by Spanish sailor [[Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira]], who called it ''San Bernardo'' (Saint Bernard). [[Pedro Fernandes de Queirós]], a Portuguese captain working for the [[Spanish monarchy|Spanish crown]], made the first recorded European landing in the islands when he set foot on [[Rakahanga]] in 1606, calling it ''Gente Hermosa'' (Beautiful People).{{cite journal |first=Brian |last=Hooker |date=1998 |journal=[[Terrae Incognitae (journal)|Terrae Incognitae]] |volume=30 |issue=1 |title=European discovery of the Cook Islands |pages=54–62|doi=10.1179/tin.1998.30.1.54 }} British navigator Captain [[James Cook]] arrived in 1773 and 1777Thomas, Nicholas (2003). ''Cook : the extraordinary voyages of Captain James Cook'', Walker & Company, {{ISBN|0802714129}}, pp. 310–311. and named the island of [[Manuae (Cook Islands)|Manuae]] ''Hervey Island''. Later, the name ''Hervey Islands'' came to be applied to the entire southern group; the name "Cook Islands", in honour of Cook, first appeared on a Russian naval chart published in the 1820s.{{cite web|url=http://www.cook-islands.gov.ck/history.php |title=Cook Islands Government website |publisher=Cook-islands.gov.ck |accessdate=18 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326003510/http://www.cook-islands.gov.ck/history.php |archivedate=26 March 2009 |df=dmy }} In 1813 [[John Williams (missionary)|John Williams]], a missionary on the ''Endeavour'' (not the same ship as Cook's) made the first recorded sighting of [[Rarotonga]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chr.org.au/fpbooks/tendecades/TEN%20DECADES%20Chapter%203.doc|title=Ten Decades: The Australasian Centenary History of the London Missionary Society, Rev. Joseph King (Word document)|accessdate=18 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928152312/http://www.chr.org.au/fpbooks/tendecades/TEN%20DECADES%20Chapter%203.doc|archivedate=28 September 2011|df=dmy-all}} {{dubious|date=February 2013|John Williams}} The first recorded landing on Rarotonga by Europeans was in 1814 by the ''Cumberland''; trouble broke out between the sailors and the Islanders and many were killed on both sides.{{cite web|url=http://www.ck/history.htm|title=History of the Cook Islands|publisher=Ck/history|accessdate=18 November 2011}} The islands saw no more Europeans until missionaries arrived from England in 1821. Christianity quickly took hold in the culture and many islanders continue to be Christian believers today. [[File:Cook Islands Annexation Ceremony.jpg|thumb|Governor [[Lord Ranfurly]] reading the annexation proclamation to [[Makea Takau Ariki|Queen Makea]] on 7 October 1900.]] The Cook Islands became a British [[protectorate]] in 1888, due largely to community fears that France might occupy the territory as it had Tahiti. On 6{{nbsp}}September 1900, the leading islanders presented a petition asking that the islands (including [[Niue]] "if possible") should be annexed as British territory.''"Commonwealth and Colonial Law"'' by Kenneth Roberts-Wray, London, Stevens, 1966. P. 891N.Z. Parliamentary Pp., A3 (1901) On 8–9 October 1900 seven instruments of cession of Rarotonga and other islands were signed by their chiefs and people; and by a British Proclamation issued at the same time the cessions were accepted, the islands being declared parts of Her Britannic Majesty's dominions. These instruments did not include [[Aitutaki]]. It appears that, though the inhabitants regarded themselves as British subjects, the Crown's title was uncertain, and the island was formally annexed by Proclamation dated 9{{nbsp}}October 1900."Commonwealth and Colonial Law" by Kenneth Roberts-Wray, London, Stevens, 1966. P. 761N.Z. Parliamentary Pp., A1 (1900) The islands were included within the boundaries of the [[Colony of New Zealand]] in 1901 by Order in CouncilS.R.O. & S.I. Rev. XVI, 862–863 under the Colonial Boundaries Act, 1895 of the United Kingdom.58 & 59 V. c. 34. The boundary change became effective on 11{{nbsp}}June 1901 and the Cook Islands have had a formal relationship with New Zealand ever since. When the British Nationality and New Zealand Citizenship Act 1948 came into effect on 1{{nbsp}}January 1949, Cook Islanders who were [[British subject]]s gained [[New Zealand citizenship]].[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/citizenship/3 3. Aliens and citizens – Citizenship – Te Ara Encyclopedia of New Zealand]. Teara.govt.nz (4 March 2009). Retrieved 26 December 2012. The country remained a New Zealand dependent territory until 1965, when the New Zealand Government decided to offer self-governing status to its colony. In that year, [[Albert Henry (politician)|Albert Henry]] of the [[Cook Islands Party]] was elected as the first Premier. Henry led the country until he was accused of vote-rigging. He was succeeded in 1978 by [[Tom Davis (Cook Islands)|Tom Davis]] of the [[Democratic Party (Cook Islands)|Democratic Party]]. ==Politics and foreign relations== {{Main|Politics of the Cook Islands|Foreign relations of the Cook Islands}} [[File:Parliament of the Cook Islands - 2006.JPG|thumb|The parliament building of the Cook Islands, formerly a hotel.]] [[File:Sustainable Development and Conservation Event in the Cook Islands (7907701948).jpg|thumb|Prime Minister [[Henry Puna]] with U.S. Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]], 31 August 2012]] The Cook Islands is a [[representative democracy]] with a [[parliamentary system]] in an [[associated state]] relationship with New Zealand. [[Executive power]] is exercised by the government, with the Chief Minister as [[head of government]]. [[Legislative power]] is vested in both the government and the [[Parliament of the Cook Islands]]. There is a pluriform multi-party system. The [[Judiciary]] is independent of the executive and the legislature. The [[head of state]] is the [[Monarchy in New Zealand|Queen of New Zealand]], who is represented in the Cook Islands by the [[Monarchy in the Cook Islands|Queen's Representative]].{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} The islands are self-governing in "free association" with [[New Zealand]]. New Zealand retains primary responsibility for external affairs, with consultation with the Cook Islands government. Cook Islands nationals are citizens of New Zealand and can receive New Zealand government services, but the reverse is not true; New Zealand citizens are not Cook Islands nationals. Despite this, {{As of|2014|lc=y}}, the Cook Islands had diplomatic relations in its own name with 43 other countries. The Cook Islands is not a United Nations member state, but, along with [[Niue]], has had their "full treaty-making capacity" recognised by [[United Nations Secretariat]],{{citation|format=PDF |url=http://legal.un.org/repertory/art102/english/rep_supp8_vol6-art102_e_advance.pdf |title=Repertory of Practice |website=Legal.un.org |number=8 |page=10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019223055/http://legal.un.org/repertory/art102/english/rep_supp8_vol6-art102_e_advance.pdf |archivedate=19 October 2013 |df=dmy }}{{citation |url=https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/world00.pdf |website=Legal.un.org |title=The World today |format=PDF}} and is a full member of the [[WHO]] and [[UNESCO]] [[List of specialized agencies of the United Nations|UN specialised agencies]], is an associate member of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific ([[UNESCAP]]) and a Member of the Assembly of States of the [[International Criminal Court]]. On 11 June 1980, the [[United States]] signed [[Cook Islands – United States Maritime Boundary Treaty|a treaty]] with the Cook Islands specifying the [[maritime boundary|maritime border]] between the Cook Islands and [[American Samoa]] and also relinquishing any American claims to [[Penrhyn Island|Penrhyn]], [[Pukapuka]], [[Manihiki]], and [[Rakahanga]].{{cite web|url=http://www.paclii.org/pits/en/treaty_database/1980/6.html|title=Treaty Between the United States of America and the Cook Islands on Friendship and Delimitation of the Maritime Boundary Between the United States of America and the Cook Islands (and Exchange of Notes)|work=Pacific Islands Treaty Series|publisher=University of the South Pacific School of Law|accessdate=18 May 2009}} In 1990 the Cook Islands and France signed [[Maritime Delimitation Agreement (Cook Islands – France)|a treaty]] that [[boundary delimitation|delimited]] the boundary between the Cook Islands and [[French Polynesia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.paclii.org/pits/en/treaty_database/1990/4.html|title=Agreement on Maritime Delimitation Between the Government of the Cook Islands and the Government of the French Republic|work=Pacific Islands Treaty Series|publisher=University of the South Pacific School of Law|accessdate=4 March 2010}} As competition between the US and China heated up in the [[South China Sea]] and other areas closer to the mainland, the Cook Islands began to feel the results. In late August 2012, for instance, [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] visited the islands.{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/trvl/2012/196973.htm|title=Secretary Clinton:Travel to the Cook Islands, Indonesia, China, Timor-Leste, Brunai, and Russia|accessdate=4 September 2012|publisher=U.S. Department of State}}{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-south-pacific-20120829,0,4251912.story|title=Hillary Clinton's visit underscores new value of Cook Islands|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=Richter|first=Paul|date=29 August 2012|accessdate=29 August 2012}} ===Human rights=== {{See also|Human rights in the Cook Islands|LGBT rights in the Cook Islands}} Male [[homosexuality]] is illegal in the Cook Islands and is punishable by a maximum term of seven years imprisonment.{{cite web|title=State Sponsored Homophobia 2016: A world survey of sexual orientation laws: criminalisation, protection and recognition|url=http://ilga.org/downloads/02_ILGA_State_Sponsored_Homophobia_2016_ENG_WEB_150516.pdf|work=[[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]]|accessdate=19 May 2016|date=17 May 2016}} ==Administrative subdivisions== There are island councils on all of the inhabited outer islands (Outer Islands Local Government Act 1987 with amendments up to 2004, and Palmerston Island Local Government Act 1993) except [[Nassau (Cook Islands)|Nassau]], which is governed by [[Pukapuka]] ([[Suwarrow]], with only one caretaker living on the island, also governed by Pukapuka, is not counted with the inhabited islands in this context). Each council is headed by a mayor. [[File:Penrhyn Aerial EFS 1280.jpg|thumb|Aerial view of Penrhyn]]
;The Ten Outer Islands Councils are: {|class="wikitable" |- |[[File:Aitutakitopo.png|70px]] |[[File:Aitutaki Aerial.jpg|70px]] |[[Aitutaki]] (including uninhabited [[Manuae (Cook Islands)|Manuae]]) |- |[[File:Atiumap.png|70px]] |[[File:Atiu Aerial.jpg|70px]] |[[Atiu]] (including uninhabited [[Takutea]]) |- |[[File:Mangaia english version.png|70px]] |[[File:Mangaia (Correct Orientation).JPG|70px]] |[[Mangaia]] |- |[[File:Manihiki.jpg|70px]] |[[File:Manihiki Aerial.jpg|70px]] |[[Manihiki]] |- |[[File:Mauke map.jpg|70px]] |[[File:Mauke Aerial.jpg|70px]] |[[Ma'uke]] |- |[[File:Mitiaro Island map.jpg|70px]] |[[File:Mitiaro Aerial.jpg|70px]] |[[Mitiaro]] |- |[[File:Palmerston Island map.jpg|70px]] |[[File:Palmerston Aerial.jpg|70px]] |[[Palmerston Island|Palmerston]] |- |[[File:Penrhyn.png|70px]] |[[File:Penhryn atoll.jpg|70px]] |[[Penrhyn Island|Penrhyn]] |- |[[File:Pukapuka.png|70px]] |[[File:Pukapuka Atoll.jpg|70px]] |[[Pukapuka]] (including [[Nassau (Cook Islands)|Nassau]] and [[Suwarrow]]) |- |[[File:Rakahanga.jpg|70px]] |[[File:ISS002-E-10047rakahanga.jpg|70px]] |[[Rakahanga]] |}
[[File:Rarotopo.png|thumb|Districts of Rarotonga]] The three ''Vaka'' councils of [[Rarotonga]] established in 1997 (''Rarotonga Local Government Act 1997''), also headed by mayors,Larmour, Peter and Barcham, Manuhuia. [https://web.archive.org/web/20090324214201/http://www.transparency.org.au/documents/cookislands.pdf Cook Islands 2004], [[Transparency International]] Country Study Report. were abolished in February 2008, despite much controversy.{{cite web |url=http://www.cook-islands.gov.ck/view_release.php?release_id=990 |title=Rarotonga Local Government (Repeal) Bill To Be Tabled, Cook Islands Government |publisher=Cook-islands.gov.ck |accessdate=17 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017220610/http://www.cook-islands.gov.ck/view_release.php?release_id=990 |archivedate=17 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}[https://web.archive.org/web/20090102015825/http://www.ciherald.co.ck/articles/h392b.htm Minister asked to answer queries over abolition of Vaka Councils]. ''The Cook Islands Herald'', No. 393 (9 February 2008) ;The three Vaka councils on [[Rarotonga]] were: {|class="wikitable" |- |[[Te-Au-O-Tonga]] |(equivalent to [[Avarua]], the capital of the Cook Islands) |- |[[Puaikura]] |Arorangi |- |[[Takitumu]] |Matavera, Ngatangiia, Takitumu |} On the lowest level, there are village committees. [[Nassau (Cook Islands)|Nassau]], which is governed by [[Pukapuka]], has an island committee (Nassau Island Committee), which advises the Pukapuka Island Council on matters concerning its own island. ==Demographics== {{main|Demographics of the Cook Islands}} {{Population pyramid |year=2011{{cite web |url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dyb2014/Table07.pdf |title=Demographic Yearbook, Population by age, sex and urban/rural residence: latest available year, 2005–2014|website=UN Data |publisher=United Nations |access-date=4 December 2015}} | m0=4.5|m5=4.3 |m10=4.5 |m15=4.3 |m20=3.4 |m25=3.3 |m30=3 |m35=3.1 |m40=3.4 |m45=3.6 |m50=3 |m55=2.4 |m60=2.2 |m65=1.9 |m70=1.4 |m75=0.7 |m80=0.5 |m85=0 | f0=4.4|f5=4.3 |f10=4 |f15=4.1 |f20=3.7 |f25=3.8 |f30=3.3 |f35=3.6 |f40=3.6 |f45=3.6 |f50=3 |f55=2.4 |f60=2 |f65=1.8 |f70=1.4 |f75=0.9 |f80=0.6 |f85=0 |mmax=4.5 |fmax=4.5 }} '''Births and deaths''' {{cite web|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dyb2.htm |title=United Nations Statistics Division – Demographic and Social Statistics |website=Unstats.un.org |date= |accessdate=2016-12-31}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:70px;"|Year ! style="width:70px;"|Population ! style="width:70px;"|Live births ! style="width:70px;"|Deaths ! style="width:70px;"|Natural increase ! style="width:70px;"|Crude birth rate ! style="width:70px;"|Crude death rate ! style="width:70px;"|Rate of natural increase ! style="width:70px;"|TFR |- style="text-align:right;" || 2009 || || 284 || 72 || 212 ||12.6 ||3.2 ||9.4 || |- style="text-align:right;" || 2010 || || 286 || 92 || 194 ||12.1 ||3.9 ||8.2 || |- style="text-align:right;" || 2011 || 14 974 || 262 || 72 || 190 ||13.6 ||3.7 ||9.8 || |- style="text-align:right;" || 2012 || || 259 || 104 || 155 ||13.3 ||5.3 ||7.9 || |- style="text-align:right;" || 2013 || || 256 || 115 || 141 ||13.8 ||6.2 ||7.6 || |} ==Economy== {{Main|Economy of the Cook Islands}} The economy is strongly affected by geography. It is isolated from foreign markets, and has some inadequate infrastructure; it lacks major natural resources, has limited manufacturing and suffers moderately from natural disasters.''Polynesia French Business Law Handbook: Strategic Information and Laws'' {{ISBN|1-4387-7081-2}} p. 130 Tourism provides the economic base that makes up approximately 67.5% of GDP. Additionally, the economy is supported by foreign aid, largely from New Zealand. [[China]] has also contributed foreign aid, which has resulted in, among other projects, the Police Headquarters building. The Cook Islands is expanding its agriculture, mining and fishing sectors, with varying success. Since approximately 1989, the Cook Islands have become a location specialising in so-called [[asset-protection trusts#Cook Islands|asset protection trusts]], by which investors shelter assets from the reach of creditors and legal authorities.{{cite web|title=Review of Offshore Jurisdictions: Cook Islands|url=http://protectyou.com/1996/01/review-of-offshore-jurisdictions-part-1/|publisher=The Asset Protection News|last1=Rosen |first1=Howard |last2=Donlevy-Rosen |first2=Patricia}} According to ''The New York Times'', the Cooks have "laws devised to protect foreigners' assets from legal claims in their home countries", which were apparently crafted specifically to thwart the long arm of American justice; creditors must travel to the Cook Islands and argue their cases under Cooks law, often at prohibitive expense. Unlike other foreign jurisdictions such as the [[British Virgin Islands]], the [[Cayman Islands]] and [[Switzerland]], the Cooks "generally disregard foreign court orders" and do not require that bank accounts, real estate, or other assets protected from scrutiny (it is illegal to disclose names or any information about Cooks trusts) be physically located within the archipelago. Taxes on trusts and trust employees account for some 8% of the Cook Islands economy, behind tourism but ahead of fishing. In recent years, the Cook Islands has gained a reputation as a debtor paradise, through the enactment of legislation that permits debtors to shield their property from the claims of creditors.{{cite news |last=Wayne |first=Leslie |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/15/business/international/paradise-of-untouchable-assets.html |title=Cook Islands, a Paradise of Untouchable Assets |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate= 27 December 2013}} ==Culture== {{main|Culture of the Cook Islands}} [[File:Rarotonga-8-Maeva-Nui.jpg|thumb|Float parade during the annual Maeva Nui celebrations.]] ===Language=== The languages of the Cook Islands include [[English language|English]], [[Cook Islands Māori]], or "[[Rarotongan]]," and [[Pukapukan language|Pukapukan]]. Dialects of Cook Islands Maori include [[Penrhyn language|Penrhyn]]; [[Rakahanga-Manihiki language|Rakahanga-Manihiki]]; the [[Nga-Pu-Toru|Ngaputoru]] dialect of [[Atiu]], [[Mitiaro]], and [[Mauke]]; the [[Aitutaki]] dialect; and the [[Mangaia]]n dialect. Cook Islands Maori and its dialectic variants are closely related to both [[Tahitian language|Tahitian]] and to New Zealand [[Māori language|Māori]]. [[Pukapukan]] is considered closely related to the [[Samoan language]]. English and Cook Islands Māori are [[official language]]s of the Cook Islands; per the [http://www.paclii.org/ck/legis/num_act/trma2003130/ Te Reo Maori Act]. The legal definition of Cook Islands Māori includes Pukapukan.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} ===Music=== {{Main|Music of the Cook Islands}} Music in the Cook Islands is varied, with Christian songs being quite popular, but traditional dancing and songs in Polynesian languages remain popular. [[File:Narrative of Missionary Enterprises engraving.jpg|thumb|Confiscation and destruction of idol gods by European missionaries in Rarotonga, 1837]] [[File:Cook Islands IMG 5905 (8451965559).jpg|thumb|The Cook Islands Christian Church]] ===Public holidays=== {{main|Public holidays in the Cook Islands}} ===Art=== {{main|Art of the Cook Islands}} ====Carving==== [[File:Cook Islands carved wood figure, British Museum.jpg|thumb|This wooden late eighteenth or early nineteenth century carved [[Deity Figure from Rarotonga|figure]] escaped [[emasculation]]. Only one other comparable example is known apart from this one in the [[British Museum]].{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/standing-male-figure/iAEuMZBGSYaByg |title=Standing male figure – Google Arts & Culture |website=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-31}}]] [[Woodcarving]] is a common art form in the Cook Islands. The proximity of islands in the southern group helped produce a homogeneous style of carving but that had special developments in each island. Rarotonga is known for its fisherman's gods and staff-gods, [[Atiu]] for its wooden seats, [[Mitiaro]], [[Mauke]] and Atiu for mace and slab gods and [[Mangaia]] for its ceremonial adzes. Most of the original wood carvings were either spirited away by early European collectors or were burned in large numbers by missionaries. Today, carving is no longer the major art form with the same spiritual and cultural emphasis given to it by the Maori in New Zealand. However, there are continual efforts to interest young people in their heritage and some good work is being turned out under the guidance of older carvers. Atiu, in particular, has a strong tradition of crafts both in carving and local fibre arts such as tapa. Mangaia is the source of many fine adzes carved in a distinctive, idiosyncratic style with the so-called double-k design. Mangaia also produces food pounders carved from the heavy calcite found in its extensive limestone caves.{{cite web|url=http://www.ck/culture.htm#visual |title=Lords of the Dance : Culture of the Cook Islands|publisher=Ck|date=2013-11-12|accessdate=2016-12-31}} ====Weaving==== The outer islands produce traditional [[weaving]] of mats, basketware and hats. Particularly fine examples of rito hats are worn by women to church. They are made from the uncurled immature fibre of the coconut palm and are of very high quality. The Polynesian equivalent of Panama hats, they are highly valued and are keenly sought by Polynesian visitors from Tahiti. Often, they are decorated with hatbands made of minuscule pupu shells that are painted and stitched on by hand. Although pupu are found on other islands the collection and use of them in decorative work has become a speciality of Mangaia. The weaving of rito is a speciality of the northern islands, Manihiki, Rakahanga and Penrhyn.{{cite web|url=http://www.ck/culture.htm#crafts |title=Lords of the Dance : Culture of the Cook Islands |publisher=Ck |date=2013-11-12|accessdate=2016-12-31}} ====Tivaevae==== A major art form in the Cook Islands is [[tivaevae]]. This is, in essence, the art of handmade Island scenery patchwork quilts. Introduced by the wives of missionaries in the 19th century, the craft grew into a communal activity, which is probably one of the main reasons for its popularity.{{cite web|url=http://www.ck/tivaevae.htm |title=Tivaevae – Quilts of the Cook Islands |publisher=Ck |date=2004-07-15 |accessdate=2016-12-31}} ====Contemporary art==== The Cook Islands has produced internationally recognised contemporary artists, especially in the main island of Rarotonga. Artists include painter (and photographer) Mahiriki Tangaroa, sculptors Eruera (Ted) Nia (originally a film maker) and master carver Mike Tavioni, painter (and Polynesian tattoo enthusiast) Upoko'ina Ian George, Aitutakian-born painter Tim Manavaroa Buchanan, Loretta Reynolds, Judith Kunzlé, Joan Rolls Gragg, Kay George (who is also known for her fabric designs), Apii Rongo, Varu Samuel, and multi-media, installation and community-project artist [[Ani O'Neill]], all of whom currently live on the main island of Rarotonga. Atiuan-based Andrea Eimke is an artist who works in the medium of tapa and other textiles, and also co-authored the book 'Tivaivai – The Social Fabric of the Cook Islands' with British academic [[Susanne Kuechler]]. Many of these artists have studied at university art schools in New Zealand and continue to enjoy close links with the New Zealand art scene.{{cite web|title=The Cook Islands Arts Community|url=http://cookislandsarts.com|website=Cookislandsarts.com|access-date=2016-04-08}} New Zealand-based Cook Islander artists include [[Michel Tuffery]], print-maker David Teata, Richard Shortland Cooper, Sylvia Marsters and [[Jim Vivieaere]]. On Rarotonga, the main commercial galleries are Beachcomber Contemporary Art (Taputapuatea, Avarua) run by Ben & Trevon Bergman,{{cite web |url=http://www.gallerybca.com |title=BCA Gallery, Beachcomber Art, Rarotonga Art, Cook Islands Art, Pacifc Art, South Pacific Art |website=Gallerybca.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161216070049/http://www.gallerybca.com/ |archive-date=16 December 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} and The Art Studio Gallery (Arorangi) run by Ian and Kay George.{{cite web|url=http://www.tautai.org/artist/ian-george/ |title=Ian George – Tautai – Guiding Pacific Artstautai – Guiding Pacific Arts |publisher=TAUTAI |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2016-12-31}} The Cook Islands National Museum also exhibits art.{{cite web|url=http://cook-islands-library-museum.org/ |title=Cook Islands Museum and Library Society | Official Website of the Cook Islands Library & Museum Society |website=Cook-islands-library-museum.org |date=1964-12-22 |accessdate=2016-12-31}} ==Wildlife== [[File:Tiaré tahiti.jpg|thumb|''[[Gardenia taitensis|Tiare māori]]'', the [[national flower]] of the Cook Islands]] * The national flower of the Cook Islands is the ''[[Gardenia taitensis|Tiare māori]]'' or ''[[Gardenia taitensis|Tiale māoli]]'' (Penrhyn, Nassau, Pukapuka).{{cite web|url=http://www.govisitcookislands.com/cook-islands/wildlife.asp|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221233523/http://www.govisitcookislands.com/cook-islands/wildlife.asp|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-12-21|website=Govisitcookislands.com|title=Cook Islands Wildlife}} * The Cook Islands have a large non-native population of ''Kiore toka'' ([[Ship rat]]).{{cite web|url=http://cookislands.bishopmuseum.org/species.asp?id=8747|title=Cook Islands Biodiversity: Rattus rattus – Ship Rat|website=Cookislands.bishopmuseum.org|accessdate=18 November 2011}} and [[Polynesian rat]].{{cite web|url=http://cookislands.bishopmuseum.org/species.asp?id=8745|title=Cook Islands Biodiversity: Rattus exulans – Pacific Rat|website=Cookislands.bishopmuseum.org|accessdate=18 November 2011}} The rats have dramatically reduced the bird population on the islands.{{cite web|url=http://cookislands.bishopmuseum.org/showarticle.asp?id=7|title=Cook Islands Biodiversity: The Status of Cook Islands Birds – 1996|website=Cookislands.bishopmuseum.org|date=24 September 2005|accessdate=18 November 2011}} * In April 2007, 27 [[Kuhl's lorikeet]] were re-introduced to [[Atiu]] from [[Rimatara]]. Fossil and oral traditions indicate that the species was formerly on at least five islands of the southern group. Excessive exploitation for its red feathers is the most likely reason for the species's extinction in the Cook Islands.{{cite web|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/species/index.html?action=SpcHTMDetails.asp&sid=1365&m=0|title=BirdLife International: Rimatara Lorikeet (Vini kuhlii) at|website=Birdlife.org|accessdate=18 November 2011}} ==Sport== {{Main|Sport in the Cook Islands}} {{see also|Cricket in Oceania#Cook Islands}} {{see also|Netball in the Cook Islands}} {{see also|Rugby league in the Cook Islands}} [[Rugby league]] is the most popular sport in the Cook Islands.{{cite web|url=http://www.wearerugby.com/news/articles/cook-islands-financial-strife|title=Cook Islands Financial Strife|publisher=We Are Rugby|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206231821/http://www.wearerugby.com/news/articles/cook-islands-financial-strife|archivedate=6 December 2011 }} ==See also== * * * [[Demographics of the Cook Islands]] * [[Index of Cook Islands-related articles]] * [[List of Cook Islanders]] * [[List of islands]] * [[Outline of the Cook Islands]] {{portal bar|Geography|Oceania||Commonwealth realms|New Zealand| United Nations|}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Gilson, Richard. ''The Cook Islands 1820–1950.'' Wellington, New Zealand: Victoria University Press, 1980. {{ISBN|0-7055-0735-1}} ==External links== {{Sister project links|voy=Cook Islands|Cook Islands}} * {{Official website|http://www.cookislands.gov.ck/ }} Cook Islands Government * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081210080320/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/world-leaders-1/world-leaders-c/cook-islands.html Chief of State and Cabinet Members] * {{CIA World Factbook link|cw|Cook Islands}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080704000127/http://ucblibraries.colorado.edu/govpubs/for/cookislands.htm Cook Islands] from ''UCB Libraries GovPubs'' * {{dmoz|Regional/Oceania/Cook_Islands}} {{Cook Islands topics}} {{Navboxes |title = Geographic locale |list1 = {{Realm of New Zealand}} {{Polynesia}} {{Countries and territories of Oceania}} }} {{Pacific Islands Forum (PIF)}} {{Culture of Oceania}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Cook Islands| ]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Oceania]] [[Category:Associated states of New Zealand]] [[Category:British Western Pacific Territories]] [[Category:Countries in Polynesia]] [[Category:English-speaking countries and territories]] [[Category:Island countries]] [[Category:New Zealand–Pacific relations]] [[Category:Small Island Developing States]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1965]]

{{Unreferenced|date=February 2008}} The '''County of Calvelage''' existed at the end of the 11th century and in the first half of the 12th century in the region of [[Vechta]] in [[Lower Saxony]], [[Germany]].
The Court of Kalvelage in the farming community of Brockdorf in [[Lohne, Germany|Lohne]] provided the name for the county. The name disappeared in the 17th century, when it was changed to "Brockdorf" by the lords of the manor from the ''[[von Galen]]'' family, who were responsible for the area.
The counts of Calvelage, who had property in [[Vechta]] and [[Bersenbrück]], acquired areas in [[Teutoburg Forest]] northwest of [[Halle, North Rhine-Westphalia|Halle]] around 1100 and erected [[Ravensberg Castle]]. They moved their main residence to the new castle around 1140 and called themselves [[County of Ravensberg|Counts of Ravensberg]] from then on.
Counts of Calvelage: *Hermann I, died probably in 1082, Count of Calvelage; after 1070 he married [[Ethelinde of Northeim]], daughter of [[Otto of Northeim]], 1061-1070 [[Rulers of Bavaria|Duke of Bavaria]], after he had been deposed and his daughter had been repudiated by his son-in-law and successor, [[Welf I, Duke of Bavaria]] 1070-1101 ([[House of Welf|Welf]]). *Hermann von Calvelage, documented to have lived 1115-1134, their son, count in 1120, Count of Calvelage in 1125. *Otto I, documented to have lived 1140-1170, probably his first son, first Count of Ravensberg; married to Oda, documented to have lived in 1166.
{{coord missing|Lower Saxony}}

{{refimprove|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox Military Structure |name=Despot Stefan Tower |location=[[Kalemegdan]], [[Belgrade]]
'''[[Serbia]]''' {{flagicon|Serbia}} |coordinates= {{coord|44|49|31|N|20|27|4|E|type:landmark_region:RS|display=inline,title}} |image=Despotova kula6.jpg |image_size=300px |caption='''Despot Stefan Tower''' in Upper City of [[Kalemegdan Fortress]] | pushpin_map = Serbia Belgrade | pushpin_map_caption = Location within Belgrade |type= |built=1405 |builder=[[Stefan Lazarević]] |materials=Stone |height= |used=[[Serbian Despotate]] |condition= |ownership= |open_to_public=Yes }} The '''Despot Stefan Tower''' ({{lang-sr|Деспотова кула}}; ''Despotova kula'') or '''Dizdar Tower''' (Диздарева кула; ''Dizdareva kula'') is a structure in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]], built ca. 1405, a couple of years after the city became the capital of [[Serbian Despotate]] under [[Despot (court title)|Despot]] [[Stefan Lazarević]]. In May 1963, representatives of the city administration, Institute for the protection of the cultural monuments and members of the astronomical societies, agreed to adapt the Dizdar Tower into an observatory. Works began in May, instruments were to be installed by autumn, and the observatory was to become operational in October 1963.{{Citation | last = | first = | author = | title = Urediće se Narodna Opservatorija na Kalemegdanu | newspaper = [[Politika]] | pages = | language = Serbian | date = 9 May 2017 | url = }} Today, the tower is the seat of the [[Astronomical Society Ruđer Bošković]] and houses its Popular Observatory. The Observatory has two instruments: refractor Zeiss (110/2200mm) and reflector Tall 200 K (200/2200mm), both of which are used mainly for observations at night. Four panoramic telescopes are also mounted on the tower, which can be used to observe the panorama of Belgrade.http://adrb.org/index.php?lang=en&page=observatory ==See also== {{commonscat|Despot Stefan Tower}} * [[Architecture in Serbia]] * [[Kalemegdan]] ==References== {{Belgrade}} [[Category:Kalemegdan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Belgrade]] [[Category:15th-century establishments in Serbia]] [[Category:Towers in Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian Despotate]] [[Category:Lazarević dynasty]] [[Category:Stone buildings]] {{Serbia-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Dniepr Balts''', a hypothetical subgroup of the Eastern Balts, are [[Balts|Baltic]] tribes that lived near the [[Dnieper River]] in the [[Bronze Age]], and later were assimilated by the [[Slavs]].
The Dniepr Balts were studied by the archaeologist [[Marija Gimbutas]], [[Lithuania]]n linguist [[Kazimieras Būga]], and by Russian scientists [[Vladimir Toporov]], [[Oleg N. Trubachev|O.Trubachev]], who analysed [[hydronym]]s at the higher [[Dnieper]] basin. They have found nearly 800 [[hydronym]]s of possibly [[Baltic languages|Baltic]] origin.
==See also== *[[Galindians]]
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080820232804/http://www.vaidilute.com/books/gimbutas/gimbutas-contents.html Marija Gimbutas. The Balts. e-book]
[[Category:Ancient peoples]] [[Category:Historical Baltic peoples]]
{{Europe-ethno-group-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Edran | logo = Edranlogo.png | type = Automobile Manufacturer | genre = | foundation = 1984 | founder = André Hanjoul | location_city = | location_country = | location = Belgium | key_people = | area_served = | industry = | products = [[Automobile]]s | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | owner = | homepage = [http://www.edran.be/ www.edran.be] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Edran''' is a [[Belgian]] automobile manufacturer. The company was founded in 1984 by André Hanjoul. The first car to be displayed in public was the [[Edran Spyder MK I]] at the 1994 [[Brussels Motor Show]]. In 2006, the company introduced its newest [[sports car]], the [[Edran Enigma]].<ref>{{cite web |title = History |work = |publisher = Edran |date = |url = http://www.edran.be/ENG/History.htm |doi = |accessdate = 2007-03-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070316025401/http://www.edran.be/ENG/History.htm |archivedate = 2007-03-16 |df = }}</ref>
==Spider Mk I== According to the company's website, the Spider Mk I has a 4-cylinder engine with 150 or {{convert|180|hp}} and a top speed of 210 km/h (150 hp) or 230 km/h (180 hp). The body is made of [[fiberglass]], [[carbon fiber]], and [[Kevlar]], giving a total weight of 710 kg.<ref>{{cite web |title = Technical data 'Spyder Mk I' |publisher = Edran |date = |url = http://www.edran.be/ENG/Spyder_Data.htm |doi = |accessdate = 2007-03-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070429154201/http://www.edran.be/ENG/Spyder_Data.htm |archivedate = 2007-04-29 |df = }}</ref>
==Enigma== According to the company's website, the Enigma has an {{convert|800|hp}}, center-mounted 8-cylinder engine. It has a top speed of 340 km/h (211 mph). The body and [[chassis]] are made of carbon fiber and Kevlar, giving the Enigma a total weight of 1,240 kg.<ref>{{cite web |title = Technical data 'Engima' |publisher = Edran |date = |url = http://www.edran.be/ENG/Enigma_Data.htm |doi = |accessdate = 2007-03-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070502170313/http://www.edran.be/ENG/Enigma_Data.htm |archivedate = 2007-05-02 |df = }}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of automobile manufacturers]] *[[List of car brands]] *[[List of Western European automobile manufacturers]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.histomobile.com/1/Edran/1994/Spyder_.htm?lan=1 The Edran Spyder] *[http://www.motorauthority.com/news/supercars/another-day-another-exotic-supercar-the-edran-enigma/ The Edran Enigma] *[http://www.edran.be/ Official website]
[[Category:Motor vehicle manufacturers of Belgium]]
{{motorvehicle-company-stub}} {{belgium-stub}}

{{pp-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox person | name = Eric the Actor | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Eric Shaun Lynch | birth_date = {{Birth date|1975|3|11}} | birth_place = [[Rodeo, California]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2014|9|20|1975|3|11}} | death_place = [[Sacramento, California]]<ref name=ELynch-MercuryNews>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/sharks/ci_22889010/howard-stern-show-regular-gives-san-jose-sharks|title=Howard Stern Show regular gives San Jose Sharks a boost|date=March 28, 2013|first=Bud|last=Geracie|publisher=''[[San Jose Mercury News]]''|accessdate=July 20, 2013}} *<sup>a</sup> "...Lynch, a 38-year-old Sacramento man confined to a wheelchair, and a 10-year regular caller to the Stern Show." — ¶ 8.</ref> | website = {{URL|https://www.myspace.com/erictheactorlynch}} }} '''Eric Shaun Lynch''' (March 11, 1975 – September 20, 2014), better known as '''Eric the Midget''' and later '''Eric the Actor''',<ref name= Fringe /> was a member of ''[[The Howard Stern Show|The Howard Stern Show's]]'' [[The Wack Pack|Wack Pack]]. Lynch was, at his peak, {{height|ft=3|in=5}} tall,<ref>From December 8, 2011 Stern interview</ref> weighed {{convert|85|lb|kg|abbr=on}}, and had various health issues. He used a motorized [[wheelchair]] for mobility.<ref name='For The Week Of 9/16/2002 to 9/20/2002'>{{cite news | first=Mark | last=Mercer | coauthors= | title=Goofing On Rosie O'Donnell And Eric The Midget. 9/19/02. 7:55am | date=2002-09-20 | publisher=MarksFriggin.com | url =http://www.marksfriggin.com/news02/9-16.htm | work =Howard Stern Show News Archives | pages = | accessdate = 2007-04-12 | language = }}</ref> Despite his poor health, he claimed to have outlived every doctor's prediction for his life expectancy.<ref>[http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1140757200 Howard Stern.com]. Howard Stern.com. Retrieved on 2011-10-29.</ref>
==Medical conditions== Eric's height was cited at between {{height|ft=3|in=0}} and {{height|ft=3|in=5}}, which is within the threshold to be considered to have [[dwarfism]]. Because of his short legs and a [[club foot]], he employed a wheelchair to get around. His other afflictions included [[stork bite]] which gave him a "blotchy" complexion<ref>[http://howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1238040000#13723 Hot but not bothered – The Howard Stern Show]. Howardstern.com (2009-03-26). Retrieved on 2011-10-29.</ref> and [[Ehlers–Danlos syndrome]], which resulted in gnarled fingers.<ref>[http://howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1151467200#6874 The big winner? – The Howard Stern Show]. Howardstern.com (2006-06-28). Retrieved on 2011-10-29.</ref>
==''The Howard Stern Show''== Eric initially called in on September 19, 2002 to discuss ''[[American Idol]]''.<ref name='For The Week Of 9/16/2002 to 9/20/2002' /><ref name=Today /> Lynch had called to respond to Stern's statements that contestant [[Kelly Clarkson]] was not overly attractive.<ref name='For The Week Of 9/16/2002 to 9/20/2002' /><ref name=Today /> Stern initially talked to Lynch with mild enthusiasm, but after an extended discussion regarding Lynch's unique voice and speaking style, Lynch revealed that he was {{height|ft=3|in=5}} tall, which piqued Stern's interest.<ref name='For The Week Of 9/16/2002 to 9/20/2002' /> Eric was frequently at odds with ''The Howard Stern Show'', its staff, its callers and its guests.<ref name=Today>{{cite web |url=http://www.today.com/id/9853210/site/todayshow/ns/today-entertainment/t/role-call/#.URNcc2ctzE4|title=Howard Stern's cast of characters, from Robin to High Pitch Eric|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|last=Popkin|first=Helen A.S.|date=2005-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1189483200|title=News from the Eric's |work=HowardStern.com|date=2007-11-09}}</ref>
Eric made one in-studio appearance on November 3, 2008 alongside two prostitutes from the [[Bunny Ranch]]. Also present were [[Dixie Chicks]] singer [[Natalie Maines]], wrestler [[Kurt Angle]] and ''American Idol'' alumna [[Diana DeGarmo]].<ref>[http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1225688400#12880 Eric's historic appearance – The Howard Stern Show]. Howardstern.com (2008-11-03). Retrieved on 2011-10-29.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/pop-cult-1.811972/eric-the-midget-howard-stern-diana-degarmo-all-meet-1.835434|title='Eric the Midget,' Howard Stern, Diana DeGarmo all meet|first=Adam|last=Abramson|work=[[Newsday]]}}</ref>
==Other media== Eric preferred to be called Eric the Actor.<ref name= Fringe /> For legal reasons, Eric requested that his full official title be "Eric the Actor, formerly known as Eric the Midget" in order to protect the "Eric the Midget" trade name.<ref name=MARKFRIG>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news.htm|title='Stern Show Summary Mar 12 2013|work=MarksFriggin.com}}</ref> Lynch made his television debut in a cameo on ''[[American Dreams]]'' in 2005.<ref name=IMDB>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1865098/|title=Eric Lynch|work=[[IMDB]]}}</ref> Lynch also appeared on ''[[Fringe (TV Series)|Fringe]]'' in 2010,<ref name=Fringe>{{cite web|url=http://watching-tv.ew.com/2010/08/02/fringe-howard-stern-eric-the-midget/ |title='Fringe' gets a visit from Howard Stern's Eric... the Actor |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|last=Tucker|first=Ken|date=2010-08-02}}</ref> ''[[In Plain Sight]]'' in 2012,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1327899600|title=Little Man, Huge Pain|work=HowardStern.com|date=2012-01-30}}</ref> and ''[[Legit (2013 TV series)|Legit]]'' in 2014. Eric appeared on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' in 2008.<ref name= IMDB />
Eric also participated in a number of [[podcast]]ing ventures. He hosted ''[[American Idol]]'' and ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' wrap-up shows including an ''American Idol'' discussion show on [[Howard 101]] which featured [[Brian Dunkleman]] as co-host.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1141966800|title=THE PRINCE VISITS THE KING|publisher=HowardStern.com|date=10 March 2006}}</ref> He made appearances on [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|TNA Wrestling]]'s web offering ''TNA Today'' alongside wrestling personalities [[Mike Tenay]] and [[Jeremy Borash]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D-DUvyNdXLA|title=TNA Today (Oct 9, 2012): Mike Tenay & Eric The Actor|work=Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|publisher=YouTube|date=6 October 2012|accessdate=25 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news12/10-22.htm |title=Stern Show News - Archive |publisher=MarksFriggin.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-02}}</ref>
==Death== On September 20, 2014 Lynch was admitted to a hospital because of heart problems. After arriving, Lynch's liver and kidneys began to shut down and he died.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/obituaries/article2610637.html |title=Sacramento resident and Stern show regular Eric the Actor dies |first=Bill |last=Lindelof |work=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |date=September 22, 2014 |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tmz.com/2014/09/21/eric-the-actor-dead-dies-howard-stern-wack-pack/ |title=Howard Stern Wack Packer Eric the Actor Dead at 39 |work=[[TMZ]] |date=September 21, 2014 |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref>
On September 21, Lynch's longtime friend and manager Johnny Fratto became the first to report his death. Fratto tweeted "I am so sorry and so sad to inform everyone that my friend Eric "The Actor" Lynch passed away yesterday afternoon!!!"<ref name="variety">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/eric-the-actor-lynch-dead-wack-packer-1201310444/|title=Eric 'The Actor' Lynch, Howard Stern ‘Wack Packer,’ Dies at 39|date=September 21, 2014|first=Alex|last=Stedman|work=Variety|accessdate=September 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/JOHNNYFRATTO/status/513779210997886976 |title=Johnny Fratto on Twitter: "I am so sorry and so sad to inform everyone that my friend Eric "The Actor" Lynch passed away yesterday afternoon!!! |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2014-09-21 |accessdate=2015-08-24}}</ref>
News of Lynch's death received considerable media attention with outlets as high profile as ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', [[CNN]] and [[TMZ]] all reporting his death. Celebrities including [[Zach Braff]], [[Zac Efron]] and [[Diana Degarmo]] among others Tweeted their condolences, with Eric's trademark sign off "bye for now" trending number one as a Twitter Hashtag. [[Jimmy Kimmel]] was so upset by the news that he called The Stern Show first thing on September 22, even though he had an infant child and it was only 4:00 am Pacific Daylight Time during the broadcast. Eric, a huge fan of [[WWE]] and the [[Oakland A's]], was mourned during telecasts of both organizations, with the on-air personalities signing off the A's broadcast by saying "bye for now." Eric's roommate Jon spoke with Howard and encouraged fans to have Eric's favorite foods, Pepsi and bacon, in his honor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marksfriggin.com/news14/9-22.htm |title=Stern Show News - Archive |publisher=MarksFriggin.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-24}}</ref>
Lynch was buried at Oakmont Memorial Park in [[Lafayette, California]].<ref>[https://www.oakmontmortuary.com/obituary/lynch-eric Oakmont Memorial Park and Mortuary]. Retrieved 2018-09-15}}</ref>
== Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Television ! style="width:50px;"| Year ! style="width:250px;"| Title ! style="width:150px;"| Role ! class="unsortable" | Episode |- | 2005 | ''[[American Dreams]]'' | Eric | "It's My Life" |- | 2010 | ''[[Fringe (TV series)|Fringe]]'' | Homeless Man | "[[The Box (Fringe)|The Box]]" |- | 2012 | ''[[In Plain Sight]]'' | Landlord | "Four Marshals and a Baby" |- | 2014 | ''[[Legit (2013 TV series)|Legit]]'' | Big Pete | "Weekend" |}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Austria}} "Für den Frieden der Welt" | image = | caption = | year = 1994 | country = Austria | artist = [[Petra Frey]] | as = | with = | language = German | languages = | composer = Alfons Weindorf | lyricist = Karl Brunner,
Johann Brunner | conductor = Herman Weindorf | place = 17th | points = 19 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1994at from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Maria Magdalena | prev_link = Maria Magdalena (song) | next = Die Welt dreht sich verkehrt | next_link = Die Welt dreht sich verkehrt }} '''"Für den Frieden der Welt"''' (For the peace of the world) was the [[Austria]]n representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1994]], performed in [[German language|German]] by [[Petra Frey]]. The song was performed twentieth on the night, following [[Greece]]'s [[Costas Bigalis]] & [[The Sea Lovers]] with "[[To Trehandiri]]" and preceding [[Spain]]'s [[Alejandro Abad]] with "[[Ella no es ella]]". At the close of voting, it had received 19 points, placing 17th in a field of 25. The song is a ballad, in which Frey explains that she is singing in the hope of bringing peace to the world. It was succeeded as [[Austria in the Eurovision Song Contest|Austrian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1995|1995 Contest]] by [[Stella Jones (artist)|Stella Jones]] singing "[[Die Welt dreht sich verkehrt]]". {{Austria in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1994}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fur Den FrieDen Der Welt}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Austria]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1994]] [[Category:1994 songs]] {{austria-stub}} {{Eurovision-stub}}

{{one source|date=May 2015}} {{coord|0|27|0|S|129|52|0|E|type:isle|display=title}}
[[Image:Karta ID RajaAmpat Isl.PNG|thumb|300px|Gag and the Raja Ampat Islands]] '''Gag Island''' is one of the [[Raja Ampat Islands]] in the [[Indonesia]]n province of [[West Papua (province)|West Papua]]. It is situated some 150 kilometres west of [[Sorong (city)|Sorong]], the provincial capital.
The island's population is approximately 450 living at [[Gambier Bay]]. This community was established in the early 1960s by people moving to the island in the hope of finding work with [[nickel]] exploration ventures at that time.
==Economy== PT Gag Nikel is company formed in 1996 as a joint venture agreement between [[BHP Billiton]] (75%) and Indonesia's state-owned mining company, PT [[Aneka Tambang]] Tbk (25%). A [[contract of work]] was awarded in February 1998, and a program of exploration and preliminary evaluation was conducted. In late 1999, the Indonesian government enacted a [[Forest Principles|forestry law]] prohibiting open cast mining in "protection forest" areas. The forest on Gag Island was subsequently reclassified as "protection forest", stopping any mining activity on the island. Subsequent to these events, the Contract of Work for Gag Island was suspended. No exploration work on the island has been undertaken since late 1999.
==Sources== *[http://sustainability.bhpbilliton.com/2004/repository/caseStudies/community27.asp [[BHP Billiton]]'s website on sustainability]
[[Category:Raja Ampat Islands]]

[[Aminath Rishfa]] | cinematography = Ibrahim Wisan | editing = | music = Ibrahim Nifar | studio = Red Production | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2017|07|06}} | runtime = | country = Maldives | language = Dhivehi }} '''''Hahdhu''''' is a 2017 Maldivian [[romantic film]] directed by Abdul Fatthah. Produced by Fattah and Niuma Mohamed under Red Production, the film stars Mariyam Azza, Ahmed Shiban and [[Aminath Rishfa]] in pivotal roles. The film was released on 6 September 2017.{{cite news|url=https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/12792 |title=Haddhu will break records: Fatthah |language=Dhivehi |work=Mihaaru |last=Adhushan |first=Ahmed |date=9 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180326151354/https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/12792 |archivedate=26 March 2018 |accessdate=26 March 2018}} == Cast == * Mariyam Azza as Yusra * Shiban Ahmed as Ali * [[Aminath Rishfa]] as Zamha * Ahmed Fairooz as Azim * [[Ali Azim]] as Hamza * [[Arifa Ibrahim]] as Ali's mother * Gulisthan Mohamed * Mariyam Shakeela * [[Fauziyya Hassan]] * Mariyam Haleem == Reception == Hahdhu received mixed reviews from critics. Aishath Maaha of ''Avas'' praised the performance of Azza and Rishfa while she criticised Shiban's acting in his debut film. Though the screenplay by Ahmed was favored, she noticed some "loopholes that restricted character development".{{cite news|url=https://avas.mv/38237 |title=Review" Praising 'Hahdhu" in a limit |language=Dhivehi |work=Avas |last=Maaha |first=Aishath|date=8 September 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327062618/https://avas.mv/38237 |deadurl=no |archivedate=27 March 2018 |accessdate=27 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:Maldivian films]] {{Maldives-film-stub}}

revision.comment: /* External links */ this strikes me as quite the opposite of an _Islamic_ organisation...
revision.text:
The '''International Freedom Alliance''' ('''IFA''') ({{lang-nl|alliantie van internationale vrijheid}}) was a proposed group announced in July 2010 by Dutch politician [[Geert Wilders]].
==History==
Wilders has stated that the IFA will be an umbrella organization for groups and individuals who "are fighting for freedom against Islam".<ref>[http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/7180827/__Wilders_werkt_aan_netwerk__.html "Wilders begint internationale beweging"]</ref><ref>[http://www.pvv.nl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3476:wilders-werkt-aan-internationaal-netwerk "Wilders werkt aan internationaal netwerk"]</ref><ref>[http://www.geertwilders.nl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1701&Itemid=1 "APNewsBreak: Dutch lawmaker forms anti-Islam group "]</ref><ref>[http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/wilders-sets-international-alliance-against-islam "Wilders sets up international alliance against Islam"]</ref><ref>[http://www.pattayadailynews.com/en/2010/07/17/dutch-politician-plans-on-global-spread-of-anti-islam-party/ "Dutch Politician Plans on Global Spread of Anti-Islam Party"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924130521/http://www.pattayadailynews.com/en/2010/07/17/dutch-politician-plans-on-global-spread-of-anti-islam-party/ |date=2010-09-24 }}</ref><ref>[http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Geert-Wilders-Anti-Muslim-Freedom-Alliance-Dutch-Politician-Wants-End-To-Islamic-Immigration/Article/201007315666139 "Dutch Politician Forms Anti-Islam Coalition"]</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1295047/Dutch-politician-says-UK-freedom-alliance-countries-Islam.html "Anti-Islamic crusader launches recruitment drive in UK"]</ref> His goal is an international alliance to end immigration of [[Islam]]ic nationals to the West and a complete ban of [[Sharia law]].
Wilders had planned to set up IFA branches in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[France]] and [[Germany]] by late 2010, but it is likely that his trial delayed these plans. "The message, 'stop Islam, defend freedom', is a message that's not only important for the Netherlands but for the whole free Western world," Wilders stated in an address to reporters at the Dutch Parliament.<ref>[http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/294757 "Dutch politician to form international anti-Muslim Coalition"]</ref><ref>[http://www.jihadwatch.org/2010/07/geert-wilderss-international-freedom-alliance.html "Geert Wilders's International Freedom Alliance!"]</ref> Wilders has also stated the new organization will not include any right-wing extremists.<ref>http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/7180827__Wilders_werkt_aan_netwerk__.html</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Geert Wilders}} *[[Islamization]] *[[Spread of Islam]] *[[Stop the Islamification of Europe]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ifreedomalliance.org/ International Freedom Alliance]

revision.comment: An article this sparse does not, in fact, need a "In popular culture" segment to lead us to your awful book.
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} [[File:Campraven.jpg|thumb|250px|Jamesway hut at [[Camp Raven]] station in [[Greenland]].]]
The '''Jamesway hut''' is a portable and easy-to-assemble [[hut]], designed for [[arctic]] weather conditions. This version of the [[Quonset hut]] was created by [[James Manufacturing Company]] of [[Fort Atkinson, Wisconsin]]. A Jamesway hut had wooden ribs and an insulated fabric covering for the Army Air Corps. Insulated blankets in 1.2 m (3 ft 11 in)-wide lengths were made with [[glass fiber]] insulation faced with flame-proof [[muslin]] and enclosed in plastic-treated [[cotton]] that was water-, vermin-, and fire-proof. The hardware (nails, fasteners, and connecting bars) was the only metal component. The whole package weighed 540 kg (1,190 lb) for a 5 metres (16 ft)-square hut. Its wooden packing [[crate]]s were designed for reuse as the hut [[floor]].
The storage/floor sections, each {{convert|1.2|by|2.4|m|abbr=on}} were made from plywood and insulated with R-7 fiberglass insulation, which provided a portable, warm and cleanable floor. The wooden arches holding up the roof were attached to the floor sections with steel fittings and wing nuts, and were strong enough to hold a winter’s snow. The arches, the key to the design, were curved, glue-laminated wooden {{convert|15|cm|in|abbr=on|0}} beams on {{convert|1.2|m|abbr=on|0}} centers that folded in quarters on steel hinges and removable pins.
The hut became famous for providing portable warmth and shelter for the U.S. Armed Forces when the Japanese invaded the far [[Aleutian Islands]] in Alaska during World War II.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9_bgaZyjnJkC&pg=PA413&lpg=PA413&dq=%22jamesway%22+huts+attu&source=bl&ots=l2C8ziRycz&sig=-6qZm0MeyWd7kqvM2Lt2SopR-ro&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QAuuU5eFJcnmsATp6oJ4&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22jamesway%22%20huts%20attu&f=false ''Thousand-Mile War: World War II in Alaska and the Aleutians'', p. 413], Brian Garfield, 1995</ref> More huts were manufactured in the late 1940s for use in the Korean War; many of these have been used by the U.S. Antarctic Program (USAP) from the initial [[Operation Deep Freeze]] operation from 1956–1961 in support of the International Geophysical Year (IGY), up to the present time.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.quonsethuts.org/huts/index.htm Quonset. The Huts.]
{{Huts}}
[[Category:Huts]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Antarctica]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Radio Station | name = KTBN-SW | image = | | city = [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] | area = [[North America]] | branding = SuperPower KTBN| slogan = | airdate = {{Start date|1987|12|26}} | last airdate = {{End date and age|2008|3|30|p=y}}| format = [[Religious broadcasting|religious radio]] | power = 100,000 [[watt]]s | owner = [[Trinity Broadcasting Network]] | website = [http://www.tbn.org http://www.tbn.org] | callsign_meaning = '''T'''rinity '''B'''roadcasting '''N'''etwork (the station's owner)| }}'''KTBN''' (formerly known as '''KUSW''') was the [[shortwave radio]] outlet of the [[Trinity Broadcasting Network]], a large [[religious broadcasting|religious]] [[International broadcasting|international broadcaster]]. The station's programming was a simulcast of the audio portion of the TBN television service.
==History== KUSW, which was also branded "The Superpower", officially launched on December 26, 1987 during the peak years of the American commercial shortwave broadcasting boom triggered by the founding of [[WRNO (shortwave)|WRNO Worldwide]]. Owned by Carlson Communications International, which owned a network of AM and FM stations in Utah, Nevada, and Arizona,<ref name="history" /> KUSW broadcast a combination of news and rock music. The station also offered a mail-order catalog of products made in the Rocky Mountains.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Berg | first = Jerome S. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Broadcasting on the Short Waves, 1945 to Today | publisher = McFarland | year = 2008 | location = | pages = 280 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-7864-3674-3}}</ref> The station's "theme song", used as an [[interval signal]] for sign-ons, sign-offs, and to signal frequency changes, was "[[Telegraph Road (song)|Telegraph Road]]" by Dire Straits.
Carlson sold the station to the TBN ministry in 1990 for approximately $2 million.<ref name="history" /><ref>Berg, p. 297.</ref> The station signed off under its old format on December 16 of that year, to be relaunched under the KTBN callsign two days later.<ref name="history">{{Citation | last = Hauser | first = Glenn | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = DX Listening Digest 11-28 | date = 2011-07-14 | year = | url = http://www.w4uvh.net/dxld1128.txt | accessdate = 2012-01-09}}</ref> To celebrate the format/ownership change, TBN founders Paul and Jan Crouch staged a televised demolition by explosion of the KUSW record library.
As early as June 2004, KTBN broadcast warnings that it would leave the air due to "lack of ''[listener]'' response".<ref>{{Citation | last = Hauser | first = Glenn | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = DX Listening Digest 4-092 | date = 2004-06-13 | year = | url = http://www.worldofradio.com/dxld4092.txt | accessdate = 2010-05-10}}</ref> Although the station continued for several years after these announcements, pages dedicated to the KTBN shortwave service were deleted from the TBN website in 2005.<ref>{{Citation | last = Hauser | first = Glenn | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = DX Listening Digest 5-057 | date = 2005-04-01 | year = | url = http://www.worldofradio.com/dxld5057.txt | accessdate = 2010-05-10}}</ref> The station ceased operations on March 30, 2008.
After its final sign-off, the station equipment, including the transmitter and antenna array, was dismantled and shipped to [[Anguilla]] in the Caribbean to be incorporated into the [[Caribbean Beacon]] radio station.<ref name="history" />
== Frequencies == At the time of its last broadcasts, KTBN could be heard on the following frequencies:
*'''English to North America''': 7.505 MHz from 0100 to 1500 [[Universal Time Coordinated|UTC]]; 15.59 MHz from 1500 to 0100 UTC.
== See also ==
* [[Trinity Broadcasting Network]] * [[International broadcasting]] * [[Shortwave Radio]]

revision.text:
'''The Letter of Majesty''' (1609) was a 17th-century European document, reluctantly signed by the Holy Roman Emperor, [[Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor|Rudolf II]], granting [[religious toleration|religious tolerance]] to both [[Protestantism|Protestant]] and [[Catholic]] citizens living in the estates of [[Bohemia]]. The letter also created a Bohemian Protestant State Church, run by said estates.Wedgwood 2005, p. 71. A similar Letter was issued for [[Silesia]].
But in 1611, Rudolf inexplicably permitted his cousin [[Leopold V, Archduke of Austria|Leopold]] to invade Bohemia with some 7,000 troops. A considerable Bohemian force drove Leopold back from the suburbs of Prague, and the Bohemian Estates called upon [[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor|Matthias]] to take over the government of their kingdom.Parker, 1997, p.8 == Notes == {{Reflist}} == References == *[[Veronica Wedgwood|Wedgwood, C.V.]] (2005). ''The Thirty Years War''. New York Review of Books. *Parker, G. (edited)(1997). ''The Thirty Years War''. Routledge. [[Category:1609 works]] [[Category:Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Category:17th-century historical documents]] {{Europe-hist-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=December 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} [[File:Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas)-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|right|200px|Map of the Falkland Islands]] This is a '''list of [[airport]]s in [[Falkland Islands]]'''. The Falkland Islands are an [[archipelago]] in the [[South Atlantic Ocean]], located about {{convert|250|nmi|lk=on}} from the coast of mainland [[South America]] and {{convert|600|nmi}} from mainland Antarctica. The archipelago, consisting of [[East Falkland]], [[West Falkland]] and 776 lesser islands, is a [[self-governing]] [[British overseas territories|Overseas Territory]] of the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.falklands.gov.fk/location.php |title=The Islands: Location |work=Falkland Islands Government web site |year=2007 |accessdate=2007-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070428023347/http://www.falklands.gov.fk/location.php |archivedate=28 April 2007 |df= }} The capital, [[Stanley, Falkland Islands|Stanley]], is on East Falkland. __TOC__ {{clear}} == Airports == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! style="text-align:left;" | [[List of settlements in the Falkland Islands|Location served]] ! style="text-align:left;" | [[ICAO airport code|ICAO]] ! style="text-align:left;" | [[IATA airport code|IATA]] ! style="text-align:left;" | Airport name |- class="sortbottom" ! colspan="4" style="text-align:left; background:#DDDDDD;" | Civil airports |- valign="top" | [[Stanley, Falkland Islands|Stanley]] | SFAL | PSY | [[Port Stanley Airport]] |- class="sortbottom" ! colspan="4" style="text-align:left; background:#DDDDDD;" | Military airports |- valign="top" | [[Mount Pleasant, Falkland Islands|Mount Pleasant]] | EGYP | MPN | [[RAF Mount Pleasant]] (Royal Air Force base) |} ===Other FIGAS Airstripshttp://www.falklandislands.com/contents/view/116/get-here/get-around/internal-flights-figas=== East Falklands: * Bleaker Island * Darwin * Douglas Station * George Island * Lively Island * North Arm * Port San Carlos * Salvador * San Carlos * Sea Lion Island * Speedwell Island
West Falklands: * Albermarle * Carcass Island * Chartres * Dunnose Head * Fox Bay * Hill Cove * New Island * Pebble Island * Port Edgar * Port Howard * Port Stephens * Roy Cove * Saunders Island * Walker Creek * Weddell Island == See also == * [[Transport in the Falkland Islands]] * [[List of airports by ICAO code: S#SF - Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas)]] * [[List of airports in the United Kingdom and the British Crown Dependencies]] * [[Wikipedia: WikiProject Aviation/Airline destination lists: South America#Falkland Islands (United Kingdom)]] == References == {{refbegin}} * {{cite web | url = http://www.icao.int/anb/aig/Taxonomy/R4CDLocationIndicatorsbystate.pdf | title = ICAO Location Indicators by State | format = [[PDF]] | publisher = [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] | date = 2006-01-12}} * {{cite web | url = http://www.unece.org/cefact/locode/fk.htm | title = UN Location Codes: Falkland Islands (Malvinas) | work=[[UN/LOCODE]] 2009-2 | publisher = [[United Nations Economic Commission for Europe|UNECE]] | date = 2010-02-08}} - includes IATA codes * [http://www.gcmap.com/search?Q=country:FK Great Circle Mapper: Airports in the Falkland Islands] - IATA and ICAO airport codes * [http://www.ourairports.com/countries/FK/ OurAirports: Airports in the Falkland Islands] - lists 13 Falkland Island airports {{refend}} ===Footnotes=== {{reflist}}

The '''Mein tribe''' of the [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]] people lives along the Forcados River in [[Delta State]], [[Nigeria]]. The Mein trace their origins to Benin City, via parts of the central [[Niger Delta]]. Important Mein settlements include Ogobiri and Kiagbodo.Alagoa, Ebiegberi Joe (2005). ''A History of the Niger Delta'', Port Harcourt: Onyoma Research Publications. {{ISBN|978-37314-5-9}}
